## Introduction
This models builds upon models LP, REG and BMW. The two regions have uneuqal development pace, and the east is developing faster, as in the case of the reforming China. The migrant workers remit money to from the east to the west, while we assume there is no migration in the other direction.

## Behavioral and accounting equations
### Exogenous variables

| Parameter | Description |
|-----------|-------------|
| $\theta$ | Tax rate |
| $\alpha_0^E$, $\alpha_0^W$ | Autonomous consumption (East, West) |
| $\alpha_1^E$, $\alpha_1^W$ | Propensity to consume out of wages (East, West) |
| $\alpha_2^E$ | Propensity to consume out of transfer payments (East) |
| $\alpha_3^E$, $\alpha_3^W$ | Propensity to consume out of net worth (East, West) |
| $\alpha_4^E$, $\alpha_4^W$ | Propensity to consume out of past period's net worth (East, West) |
| $\delta$ | Depreciation rate |
| $k$ | Target capital-output ratio |
| $\gamma$ | Adjustment parameter towards target capital stock |
| $\mu^E$, $\mu^W$ | Import propensity (East, West) |
| $\beta$ | Transfer rate on wages |
| $G^E$, $G^W$ | Government expenditure (East, West) |
| $r_d$ | Interest rate on deposits |
| $r_b$ | Interest rate on bonds |
| $p_b$ | Price of bonds |
| $\lambda_{12}^E$, $\lambda_{12}^W$ | Effect of deposit rate on cash demand (East, West) |
| $\lambda_{22}^E$, $\lambda_{22}^W$ | Effect of deposit rate on deposit demand (East, West) |
| $\lambda_{32}^E$, $\lambda_{32}^W$ | Effect of deposit rate on bond demand (East, West) |
| $\lambda_{13}^E$, $\lambda_{13}^W$ | Effect of bond rate on cash demand (East, West) |
| $\lambda_{23}^E$, $\lambda_{23}^W$ | Effect of bond rate on deposit demand (East, West) |
| $\lambda_{33}^E$, $\lambda_{33}^W$ | Effect of bond rate on bond demand (East, West) |
| $\lambda_{14}^E$, $\lambda_{14}^W$ | Effect of income-to-wealth ratio on cash demand (East, West) |
| $\lambda_{24}^E$, $\lambda_{24}^W$ | Effect of income-to-wealth ratio on deposit demand (East, West) |
| $\lambda_{34}^E$, $\lambda_{34}^W$ | Effect of income-to-wealth ratio on bond demand (East, West) |

### Consumption

$$ C^E = \alpha_0^E + (1-\theta)(\alpha_1^E \cdot WB^E + \alpha_3^E \cdot R^E) + \alpha_4^E \cdot V^E \tag{1}$$

$$ C^W = \alpha_0^W + (1-\theta)[\alpha_1^W \cdot WB^W + \alpha_2^W \cdot NT + \alpha_3^W \cdot (+r_{-1}·ME_{-1} + r_{-1}·BE_{-1})] + \alpha_4^W \cdot V^W \tag{2} $$

$$WB^E = Y^E - r_{l-1} \cdot L^E_{-1} - AF^E \tag{3}$$

$$WB^W = Y^W - r_{l-1} \cdot L^W_{-1} - AF^W \tag{4}$$

### Capital Investment

$$AF^E = \delta \cdot K^E_{-1} \tag{5}$$

$$AF^W = \delta \cdot K^W_{-1} \tag{6}$$

$$K^T_E = k \cdot Y^E_{-1} \tag{7}$$

$$K^T_W = k \cdot Y^W_{-1} \tag{8}$$

$$I^E = \gamma \cdot (K^T_E - K^E_{-1}) + AF^E \tag{9}$$

$$I^W = \gamma \cdot (K^T_W - K^W_{-1}) + AF^W \tag{10}$$

$$K^E = K^E_{-1} + I^E - AF^E \tag{11}$$

$$K^W = K^W_{-1} + I^W - AF^W \tag{12}$$

$$\Delta L^E = I^E - AF^E \tag{13}$$

$$\Delta L^W = I^W - AF^W \tag{14}$$

$$L^E = L^E_{-1} + \Delta L^E \tag{15}$$

$$L^W = L^W_{-1} + \Delta L^W \tag{16}$$

$$L = L^E + L^W \tag{17}$$

### Trade and transfers

$$IM^E = \mu^E \cdot DI^E \cdot (1-\theta) \tag{18}$$

$$IM^W = \mu^W \cdot DI^W \cdot (1-\theta) \tag{19}$$

$$X^E = IM^W \tag{20}$$

$$X^W = IM^E \tag{21}$$

$$NT = WB^E \cdot \beta \tag{22}$$

### Interest payments

$$r_{l-1} \cdot L_{-1} = r_{l-1} \cdot L^W_{-1} + r_{l-1} \cdot L^E_{-1} \tag{23}$$

$$r_{d-1} \cdot M_{-1} = r_{d-1} \cdot M^W_{-1} + r_{d-1} \cdot M^E_{-1} \tag{24}$$


### Government
$$Y^E = C^E + I^E + G^E + X^E - IM^E \tag{25}$$

$$Y^W = C^W + I^W + G^W + X^W - IM^W \tag{26}$$

$$T^E = Y^E \cdot \theta \tag{27}$$

$$T^W = Y^W \cdot \theta \tag{28}$$

$$G = G^E + G^W \tag{29}$$

$$T = T^E + T^W \tag{30}$$

$$\Delta B = G + B_{-1} - B^{CB}_{-1} - r_{d-1} \cdot M^{CB}_{-1} - T \tag{31}$$

$$B = B_{-1} + \Delta B \tag{32}$$

### Portfolio decisions

$$r_b = \frac{1}{p_b} \tag{33}$$

$$CG^E = \Delta p_b \cdot B^E_{-1} \tag{34}$$

$$CG^W = \Delta p_b \cdot B^W_{-1} \tag{35}$$

$$DI^E = Y^E - T^E - NT + r_{d-1} \cdot M^E_{-1} + B^E_{-1} \tag{36}$$

$$DI^W = Y^W - T^W + NT + r_{d-1} \cdot M^W_{-1} + B^W_{-1} \tag{37}$$

$$V^E = V^E_{-1} + Y^E - C^E - T^E - NT + r_{d-1} \cdot M^E_{-1} + B^E_{-1} + CG^E \tag{38}$$

$$V^W = V^W_{-1} + Y^W - C^W - T^W + NT + r_{d-1} \cdot M^W_{-1} + B^W_{-1} + CG^W \tag{39}$$

$$\frac{M^E}{V^E} = \lambda_{20}^E + \lambda_{22}^E \cdot r_d + \lambda_{23}^E \cdot r_b + \lambda_{24}^E \cdot \left(\frac{DI^E}{V^E}\right) \tag{40}$$

$$\frac{M^W}{V^W} = \lambda_{20}^W + \lambda_{22}^W \cdot r_d + \lambda_{23}^W \cdot r_b + \lambda_{24}^W \cdot \left(\frac{DI^W}{V^W}\right) \tag{41}$$

$$\frac{p_b \cdot B^E}{V^E} = \lambda_{30}^E + \lambda_{32}^E \cdot r_d + \lambda_{33}^E \cdot r_b + \lambda_{34}^E \cdot \left(\frac{DI^E}{V^E}\right) \tag{42}$$

$$\frac{p_b \cdot B^W}{V^W} = \lambda_{30}^W + \lambda_{32}^W \cdot r_d + \lambda_{33}^W \cdot r_b + \lambda_{34}^W \cdot \left(\frac{DI^W}{V^W}\right) \tag{43}$$

$$H^E = V^E - M^E - B^E \tag{44}$$

$$H^W = V^W - M^W - B^W \tag{45}$$

$$M = M^E + M^W \tag{46}$$

$$B^{CB} = B - B^W - B^E \tag{47}$$

$$M^{CB} = M - M^W - M^E \tag{48}$$

$$H = B^{CB} + M^{CB} \tag{49}$$

Redundant equations:

$$H = H^E + H^W \tag{50}$$

### Challenges

The central bank is too accomodative. It not only absorbs all the excess bond but also the excess deposit. 

Also the central bank balances of both bond and depsoit could go negative, which means that the cash balance of the houshold might also go negative, if the household have full autonomy in portfolio decisions.
